awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Establishment of a Computer Engineering Research Lab (CERL) at Southern University and A&M College
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Southern University and A&M College will enhance undergraduate education in the Department of Electrical Engineering by establishing the  Computer Engineering Research Lab (CERL) and preparing students to meet the needs of the workforce or advanced studies with industry-like research experiences.  

The project has the objectives to: establish the CERL; implement and develop web-based and mobile-based applications; provide research experiences for undergraduate students; and develop a summer research program for senior high school students and teachers. The CERL will provide undergraduate students with practical skills through industry based-courses and projects in areas such as robotics, the Internet of Things, and smart technologies. The lab experience will offer tools, research opportunities, lectures, and mentoring to undergraduate students. The project is guided by formative and summative evaluation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY AND A & M COLLEGE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed a new Computer Engineering Research Lab (CERL) in the Electrical Engineering Department at Southern University and A&M College (SUBR). The CERL is designed to provide undergraduate STEM students with industry-like experiences needed to equip them for either working in industry or pursuing their graduate studies. The CERL provides undergraduate STEM students with knowledge and practical skills through implementing numerous industry-relevant projects.

The novelty of the CERL lies in collaborative hands-on innovative research projects related to modern industrial applications among different levels of undergraduate students primarily in the Electrical Engineering Department at Southern University.  Moreover, CERL projects provide STEM majors with industrial-based knowledge that will help them advance in their careers. The offered projects are available on a CERL-Web database for faculty, undergraduate STEM students, and high-school students and their teachers.

The project offered training for high-school teachers which allow them to transfer the acquired knowledge and practical skills to their students in the classrooms. This affected the retention of their students in their schools. The CERL also provides high-school teachers and students with practical skills and knowledge in many applications as well as how to conduct experiments related to the Electrical and Computer Engineering field.  This project also develops these skills through workshops and school visits that have been organized by the research team.

This grant support many workshops and visits of the project research team to high schools to introduce to them the importance of the Electrical Engineering program in the industry. As a result, the enrollment in the Electrical Engineering Department at SUBR was increased based on the available latest updated statistics from the University.

The offered learning resources at the CERL-Web database helped the instructors of the targeted courses in the Electrical Engineering Department to improve their teaching style by using the offered industry-based projects as class projects (with the help of the research team). This increased the students? performance and their practical skills in those targeted classes and helped students understand the topics of the selected courses. There was a noticeable increase and improvement in the practical skills of students who used the CERL and this was reflected by their grades in the selected courses. As a result, the retention of the students who used the CERL in the Electrical Engineering Department is high.

The success of this project has increased the participation of HBCU graduates in the technology and industry-based workforce. As a result, an important outcome that was achieved by this project is producing eighteen (18) leaders. The eighteen (18) students who were trained in the three-year period of the project acquired high skills such as how to perform research, how to work in teams, and how to lead and organize events. All of these students joined the industry with internships or job offers because of the high knowledge and industry-based skills they received from this project.

The CERL and CERL-Web database were implemented not only to help electrical engineering students but also for use by other engineering departments at Southern University as well as high-school students and teachers. As a result, these resources were used as a recruiting tool to place more high school students into the engineering pipeline.


Last Modified: 09/24/2022
Modified by: Yasser Ismail
